Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: EAGER: Fusion of Data and Power for a Controllable Delivery Power Grid

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Currently, electrical power distribution systems rely on permanently energized grids - electricity is transmitted constantly from the provider to users. Consequently, loads can be connected to the power grid without prior consent from the provider, giving rise to discretionary load access and thereby straining the grid's stability. Safety margins are required to satisfy sudden and spontaneous demands. At the same time, the intermittent availability of renewable sources adds yet another pressing condition on balancing existing grids. Finally, the discretionary and essentially unrestricted access to power comes at the price of grid vulnerabilities, such as cascading failures. The PIs propose a proactive digital management approach to the power grid called the controlled-delivery grid (CDG), which is cognizant of the load before energy is delivered. Users have specific addresses and issue requests for energy in advance and for a specific duration of time in the CDG. Distribution points then manage the amount and duration of energy delivery.

The PIs central hypothesis is that techniques derived from network management and control research can be applied to the smart grid enabling more efficient, more robust, and more secure delivery of energy. This high-risk / high-reward proposal will investigate feasibility of this approach. Through the implementation and use of a micro-grid test bed, the PIs propose to analyze the feasibility of fusion of digital data and high-voltage signals and demonstrate seamless integration of alternative energy sources (e.g., solar energy) with the micro-grid while using the CDG's framework. The PIs will also study methods for allocation and distribution of electrical power for a CDG framework. The novel concept ascertains targeted delivery of energy to specific users, thus simultaneously minimizing overall power overhead and conservation of non-renewable energy resources. This new grid will also increase robustness against failures and enable sudden resumption of service through proactive surge management, an ability to negotiate reduced power rates in return for lower consumption in real time, and an ability to route energy from alternative sources back to the grid without compromising grid stability.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, the PIs demonstrate how to supply energy to loads of a microgrid based on the assignment and transmission of discrete amounts of energy. The PIs coin this approach as digital energy. A digital energy grid transmits energy in discrete amounts and an addressable format. In the proposed approach, loads and power sources proactively interact with each other by having loads request the amount of energy needed and the sources grant and supply the requested energy that falls within their generation/storage capacity and service policies. The combination of a request-grant service protocol and the discretization of energy enables finer management of the supply, distribution, generation, and expenditure of energy in the grid. The approach to achieving digital energy follows the operation principles the Internet uses to exchange and manage the delivery of information.

The PIs have demonstrated the concept of digital energy in this project by performing both theoretical research on the benefits and complexities of the distribution of digital energy and experiments that show the exchange of energy in two test beds designed for these proof-of-concept experiments. The first test bed is used to show the fusion of a data network and the distribution lines of a microgrid operation to control the distribution of energy. The test bed comprises a data network and a power network. The data network carries the energy requests made by loads and grants issued by the distributor or power to notify loads about the energy granted. The power network carries power to the requesting loads.

The second test bed showcases the principles adopted in the first test bed plus the supply of discrete amounts of energy. This test bed uses communicating loads that, besides operating under the request-grant protocol, also use energy storage units built with supercapacitors. Load and sources can now negotiate different schedules and supply rates as energy amounts that loads and sources can control. The test bed showcases how a grid distributes energy in (discrete) bits, and yet loads consume it continuously, mimicking the operation of today's loads.

Six undergraduate students, two Ph.D. students, and two M.S. students took part in this project. The participation of these students went beyond gaining training and experience in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM). They also largely contributed to the project by offering fresh and unbiased views on methods to achieve digital energy. Such a contribution was possible because of their gained an understanding of different disciplines and the hands-on opportunities that this project provided to them. The activities of this project allowed the students to be closely involved in principles of energy, power, computing, and networking. They experimented with the construction of the test beds, simulation, hardware and software design, and analysis of algorithms.  The feedback from students is that this project offered them an opportunity to learn a direct application of theories on actual experiments and to exercise designs like a real experience that will help them in their professional careers and search for jobs and continue to graduate school.

The PIs have presented the results of the research on this project in six conferences, two journal articles, and two invited talks (by the PIs) by the time of writing this report. Other publications are still under review. For technology transfers, the PIs have filed three invention disclosures to the home institution, where one is a U.S. patent, one is a patent application, and another is a provisional patent. NJIT is currently offering these licenses and technologies to companies.

While the PIs and students have successfully reached the goals of this project, the outcomes have generated additional and essential questions that motivate future research. At the same time, the PIs are making the developed test beds available for experiments to other researchers.
